entry.title: Designing for the Humans Behind Internal Tools: My Experience in a B2B Product Environment
entry.content:
When people think about product design, they often picture sleek consumer apps, playful micro-interactions, and interfaces built to impress. But designing internal tools in a B2B setup is a completely different world, more quieter, deeper, and far more complex world. In my time working on internal enterprise tools at SAP, I learned that clarity is not just a design principle; it’s a lifeline. And behind every “internal user” is a human trying to do their job without friction.

Internal tools may never appear on marketing websites, but their impact is profound. They influence efficiency, accuracy, and the emotional experience of employees who rely on them day after day. That realization shifted not just how I designed, but how I listened, observed, and empathized.

Seeing the Humans Behind the Screens

It’s easy to assume that internal users are experts who already know every acronym, every workflow, and every hidden rule. But the reality is different. Internal tools are often dense, legacy-driven, and layered with years of business logic. Even experienced users can feel lost.

The biggest shift in my approach was treating internal users with the same empathy we give external customers. They deserve legibility, emotional ease, and moments of clarity just as much , if not more. Internal users don’t get guided onboarding videos or marketing-style product tours. They jump straight into complex systems, often juggling multiple responsibilities at once. Designing with this in mind meant prioritizing legibility, reducing mental effort, and ensuring every step felt intentional and supportive. It also meant acknowledging emotional factors : the frustration caused by unclear pathways, the hesitation before clicking a critical button, or the relief when a workflow simply “makes sense.”

Why always design for a First-Time User ?

One of the most impactful parts of my work was dissecting user flows not from the perspective of a product expert, but from that of a normal user behind the screen. This meant breaking down each step, identifying friction areas, and asking:

  • Would this make sense on the first try?

  • Where might someone hesitate?

  • Is the next step predictable?

This approach helped uncover pain points that would otherwise be overlooked. Redesigning flows with the same energy and curiosity that we bring to complex edge cases ensured a more holistic experience for everyone , not just the power users. Explanations should never be a one-time thing. Interfaces evolve, workflows change, and users switch contexts constantly, which means even product experts can feel like first-time users on any given day. Clear guidance, consistent cues, and small but intentional pieces of always-available information prevent friction before it appears. Designing for first-time users doesn’t mean oversimplifying; it means making the experience understandable without assumptions. A little more clarity is never unhelpful. It builds confidence, reduces cognitive load, and ensures that whether someone is new or highly experienced, the UI supports them with the same level of care every time they return.

Designing for Understanding, Not Just Completion

Clarity became a central part of the user experience. Often, this meant advocating for simple but powerful additions:

  • Tooltips to explain complex business terms

  • Message strips that guide users on what to do next

  • Inline cues to reduce ambiguity

Even closure points became important. Adding a gentle toast message confirming the end of a workflow gave users a sense of completion and confidence. In internal tools, these small reinforcements make tasks more predictable and emotionally easier. These were not ornamental additions : they were essential interactions that reduced ambiguity in critical workflows. Even something as small as a well-placed tooltip could prevent misinterpretation and save users from repeated trial-and-error. Designing for internal systems reminded me that user attention is valuable; it should not be spent deciphering jargon or guessing next steps.

Making Business Language Human-Friendly

Internal tools are filled with terminology that can overwhelm even experienced users. Improving the legibility of business terms becomes a core part of designing for internal tools. Content design is as much needed as the user experience of the workflows.  Good internal design is a culmination of creating easy simplified workflows and making them understandable without extra training. Hence, improving business term legibility became a central part of my design work. Simplifying labels, rephrasing instructions, and breaking down complex concepts helped users focus on their tasks rather than decoding language.

Bringing Stakeholders Into the Process

Another crucial element was transparency with stakeholders — product managers, engineering managers, and other decision-makers. For every major initiative, I created structured process documents that offered:

  • A clear overview of the problem

  • The user journey and its pain points

  • Research findings and insights

  • Iteration timelines

  • Rationale behind each design decision

This level of clarity helped build alignment, earned trust, and ensured everyone understood why a design change mattered. It also strengthened the collaboration between design, product, and engineering.  Stakeholders could see the depth of research, empathize with user pain points, and understand why certain design choices were necessary. It transformed conversations from subjective opinions into grounded, user-informed discussions. In many cases, it became a shared reference point that made decision-making faster and more evidence-driven.

The Quiet Impact of Good Internal Design

Working on internal tools taught me that design’s impact is often invisible but deeply felt. When internal workflows are smooth:

Work becomes faster, with fewer interruptions.
Errors decrease because the system is easier to understand.
Confidence rises as users feel supported instead of overwhelmed.
And most importantly, work becomes less stressful.

These are the small, quiet victories of internal product design. They don’t show up on landing pages, but they shape the everyday work life of employees across the organisation. Designing internal tools reminded me that design is ultimately about understanding people and even when the tools are not customer-facing. Especially then.

entry.title: String dates stopped working
entry.content:
Hi Community,
I have a question in webI report
for example: I have
1. date 1 in date/time format from the universe. create a variable on top of this like =FormatDate([Plan Date];"Mmm-yyyy").this column dates ranges from Jan-2020 to Apr-2030.
2. start date =FormatDate(ToDate("01/Sep/2016"; "dd/MMM/yyyy"); "Mmm-yyyy")
3. end date=If (ToNumber(FormatDate(CurrentDate(); "dd")) <= 15) Then FormatDate(RelativeDate(CurrentDate(); --2; MonthPeriod ); "Mmm-yyyy") Else FormatDate(RelativeDate(CurrentDate(); -1; MonthPeriod ); "Mmm-yyyy")

entry.title: Re: SAP SuccessFactors Time Off 2026 leave balance
entry.content:
Hi @s0026444332 

For your requirements it is possible to achieve with 2 scenarios.

1. Automation

 In the time account type configuration, set the "Account Creation Automation" and "Level Of Accrual Automation" as "Automatic creation" and define the required "Account Creation Offset [Months]" as "-1" so the account gets created in previous  year December and "Accrual Creation Offset [Days]" as "-25" so the accrual happens after the account creation. 

Duration for account creation and accrual creation can be customized, always account creation has to happen in prior to accrual.

Based on the configuration, auto scheduler will be created in Time Off calendar and gets executed on it's own.

2. Manual Accrual run

In Time Off calendar, you have to run the job manually in advance for account creation and accrual execution in much advance to the year end. 

So users can able to view the next year account along with balance in advance.

Thanks

Arun

entry.title: Re: Can't open Installation due to the error "User does n...
entry.content:
The reason you are unable to access the provided installation number is due to the absence of the required authorization. As outlined in KBA 3469559 - Authorization required to view my company's installation numbers - SAP for Me. 

To resolve this issue, you can request the necessary authorizations by contacting your company's Super Administrators, whose details can be found in https://me.sap.com/userscontacts/impcont, or use the self-service request according to KBA 2891528 - How to use the Self-Service Authorization Request - SAP for Me.

entry.title: Recommendation/Best Practice for SAP Master Data Governance Extensibility in Classic Mode
entry.content:
Introduction to Clean Core in S/4HANA

With the introduction of MDG Cloud Ready Mode in SAP S/4HANA 2023, SAP has significantly intensified its emphasis on maintaining a clean core. SAP’s objective is clear: Organizations must transition toward a clean core, a system landscape where customizations are isolated from the core application, ensuring long-term stability, predictable upgrades, and seamless adoption of innovations delivered by SAP.

Customers opting for Cloud Ready Mode encounter stricter guardrails around extensibility. Traditional enhancement patterns—such as modifications, implicit enhancements, or pervasive use of custom code within standard classes—are heavily restricted. Only those extension approaches that guarantee lifecycle stability and upgrade resilience are supported.

Implications for MDG Customers in Classic Mode

For organizations currently using MDG in Classic Mode, but intending to maintain system stability and ensure smooth, low-effort upgrades, it becomes essential to adopt an extension strategy that aligns closely with clean-core guidelines. The extension approach must strike a balance between functional requirements and long-term maintainability, particularly in upgrade-intensive environments.

Organizations in Classic Mode face pressing questions:

  • How do we continue enhancing MDG without jeopardizing upgrade stability?
  • Which extensibility options remain viable, and which should be avoided?
  • How can we design custom logic that aligns with SAP’s forward-looking roadmap?
  • What development patterns minimize rework in future upgrades?

Recommended Extensibility Approach

Following SAP’s clean-core philosophy, the recommended extensibility hierarchy is as follows:

1. Key User In-App Extensibility

Preferred for UI and lightweight business logic enhancements, designed to be upgrade-safe and lifecycle-stable

2. Side-by-Side Extensibility

Ideal for more complex or custom business processes using SAP BTP, providing isolation from the S/4HANA digital core while ensuring deep integration through released APIs and events

3. Classic Extensibility

Classic extensions remain available in MDG Classic Mode, but they should be used sparingly and only when clean-core options cannot fulfil the requirement.

Classic extensibility includes:

  • BADIs specific to MDG
  • Enhancement points
  • Derivation and validation exits
  • Custom code within allowed enhancement frameworks

Considerations for MDG Extension Design

There have been attempts in Classic Mode to build wrapper classes around SAP standard MDG classes with the intention of stabilizing custom logic across upgrades. However, given the expanding set of released APIs and whitelisted objects, attempting to wrap all MDG-specific classes is time-consuming.

A more sustainable approach is to rely on:

  • Released MDG APIs, frameworks, and BAdIs
  • Workflow and rule-based configurability
  • Event-driven extension patterns via SAP BTP
  • Governance processes aligned with clean-core principles

 

Below table will outline the recommended and prioritized extension options for MDG in Classic Mode, offering guidance for customers seeking to preserve upgrade stability while aligning with SAP’s recommended enhancement strategy.

We will continue to revise and update the above list, as and when new scenarios and capabilities are identified.

entry.title: Why 345% ROI Is Possible — When ERP Modules Talk: The Power of SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Article Teaser:
Integration reduces cost and risk when ERP modules and third-party systems share data reliably. SAP Integration Suite provides the platform, patterns, and tooling to connect modules, cut manual work, and deliver large returns over time.

Overview: Why Module Integration Matters

Disconnected modules create duplicate data, delayed processes, and manual reconciliation. Integration turns isolated systems into coordinated services. When ERP, CRM, SCM, HR, and analytics speak the same language, teams act faster and errors drop.

What SAP Integration Suite Provides

  • Prebuilt adapters and connectors: ready integrations for SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, and common third-party systems.
  • API management: central lifecycle control for APIs, security policies, and rate limits.
  • Event-driven architecture: support for asynchronous messaging, event mesh, and reactive flows.
  • Orchestration and mapping: design integration flows with transformation, enrichment, and routing.
  • Hybrid support: secure connectivity across cloud and on-prem landscapes via Cloud Connector.

Key Integration Patterns

Architects should choose patterns based on latency, consistency needs, and transaction scope:

  • Request-Reply (synchronous): use for immediate user-facing operations where response time is critical.
  • Event Notification (asynchronous): preferred for decoupling systems and scaling; use event mesh and durable queues.
  • Change Data Capture (CDC): publish database changes to downstream consumers to keep data near real-time without heavy ETL.
  • SAGA (compensation): implement long-running business transactions that require distributed rollback logic.
  • API Façade: present a single, stable API for consumers while hiding backend module changes.

Technical Best Practices

  • Model canonical data: create a canonical schema to reduce mappings and preserve business meaning across modules.
  • Idempotent operations: design endpoints so retries do not cause duplicate side effects.
  • Secure by design: enforce OAuth2, mTLS for connectors, and strict role-based access control for APIs.
  • Error handling and observability: centralize logs, traces, and metrics; alert on integration latency and message loss.
  • Performance tuning: right-size virtual warehouses/containers, parallelize transforms, and push down heavy transformations to the database or target engine.
  • CI/CD for integrations: store integration flows and mapping specs in Git, run automated tests, and use blue/green or canary deploys for runtime changes.

Data Consistency and Latency Tradeoffs

Designers must choose consistency vs. latency:

  • Strong consistency: synchronous calls or transactional bridging; suitable for payment or ledger updates.
  • Eventual consistency: asynchronous updates that converge over time; ideal for inventory snapshots, reporting, and analytics.

Use CDC plus materialized views or near-real-time caches to give analytics systems fresh data without burdening operational databases.

Security, Governance, and Compliance

Integration increases the attack surface. Lock it down:

  • Use centralized API gateway policies for authentication, authorization, and threat protection.
  • Implement data masking and field-level encryption for sensitive attributes.
  • Log lineage and provide traceability for audit and compliance requirements.
  • Apply tenant and region isolation when handling multi-country data to meet local data residency rules.

Measuring Value: Where the ROI Comes From

Integration Suite delivers measurable gains across three areas:

  • Cost reduction: fewer point-to-point interfaces, reduced manual reconciliation, lower middleware licensing, and ops overhead.
  • Process acceleration: automated order flows, faster settlement, and reduced lead time — speeding cash conversion cycles.
  • Decision speed: near-real-time data for analytics reduces decision latency and avoids costly delays.

Studies and vendor analyses have reported combined ROI figures (including hard and soft benefits) in the hundreds of percent over a 2–3 year horizon for well-executed integrations. The exact figure depends on scale, baseline inefficiency, and scope of automation.

Realistic Implementation Roadmap

  1. Assess and map: inventory systems, data models, and business events across modules.
  2. Define canonical model: pick core entities and common taxonomy.
  3. Prioritize flows: start with high-value, low-risk integrations (e.g., order-to-cash or procure-to-pay).
  4. Build with prebuilt connectors: use Integration Suite adapters and API Management to accelerate delivery.
  5. Automate testing and observability: validate data accuracy and monitor SLAs.
  6. Scale and govern: iterate, add event patterns, and enforce governance guards.

Common Pitfalls to Avoid

  • Building point-to-point integrations without a strategy leads to brittle landscapes.
  • Neglecting data modeling increases mapping complexity and runtime errors.
  • Underestimating governance creates security and compliance drift.
  • Rushing to synchronous designs for all flows harms scalability.

Conclusion

SAP Integration Suite is not just middleware. It is a strategic layer that enables modules to operate as a cohesive, responsive enterprise. With the right architecture, design patterns, and governance, organizations replace manual effort with automated flows and convert integration into measurable business value. That is how significant ROI numbers become achievable.

Engage Further

If you want implementation examples, reference architectures, or a checklist for your first five integration flows, ask here or share your environment details. I’ll post a template you can adapt.

entry.title: Add Custom Sheet for MIC Assignment in Master Recipe Migration Template (S/4HANA FS02)
entry.content:
Dear SAP Team,

I hope you are doing well.

I am working on the data migration for Master Recipes in SAP S/4HANA FS02 (Fiori). I need to assign MICs (Master Inspection Characteristics) during the migration process. In the SAP Public Cloud, additional sheets such as “Operation Inspection Characteristics” and “Phase Inspection Characteristics” are available in the Master Recipe migration template for this purpose.

However, in S/4HANA FS02 On-Premise/FES, these sheets are not included, and currently there is no option to assign MICs through the standard data migration template.

I would like to understand:

  1. Why SAP has not provided these sheets in the S/4HANA FS02 migration template, whereas the same functionality exists in Public Cloud.

  2. Whether there is any SAP Note, OSS guidance, or recommended workaround for assigning MICs to master recipes during data migration in S/4HANA.

  3. If it is possible to customize the migration template or if SAP plans to include this feature in future updates.

We need this functionality as part of our project deliverables, so your guidance will be highly appreciated.

Thank you for your assistance.
MAN Production Planning (PP) SAP Responsible Design and Production @SAP @Expert SAP Community @SAPSAP

entry.title: Re: Customer Consignment - Initial Stock Posting
entry.content:
To post initial entry of customer consignment stock, you can select "Goods Receipt - Others" with movement type 561 W in MIGO.

If you would like to mass upload the material inventory balance, please use the app Migrate Your Data - Migration Cockpit to migrate your data. You can refer to the test script in scope item 2Q2 - Data Migration to SAP S/4HANA from Staging for step by step procedure.

Please also refer to following online documentation and KBA about migration object "Material inventory balance" for your information:

Migration Objects for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - Material inventory balance
2813720 - SAP S/4HANA Migration cockpit: Collective KBA for migration object "Material inventory balance" (SIF_INVENTORYBAL / SIF_INVENTORY_2) - SAP for Me

entry.title: Inquiry about DI API for Cash Flow Report in SAP Business One
entry.content:
Dear SAP Support Team,
I am seeking technical guidance regarding the Cash Flow Report in SAP Business One (accessible via: Reports → Financial → Financial → Cash Flow).
In the Cash Flow - Selection Criteria interface, there are numerous complex filtering options, such as:
  • Date range (From/To)
  • Time Interval options (Daily,Weekly,Monthly,Quarterly,Semi-annually, etc.)
  • Branch (filtering by GL accounts, business partners, etc.)
  • Include Projected Postings
  • Branch
My Question:
Does SAP Business One provide a DI API (Data Interface API) interface to programmatically access and generate the Cash Flow Report with these selection criteria? If yes, could you please provide:

  1. Any documentation or SDK references specifically for the Cash Flow Report DI API
I have reviewed the standard DI API documentation but would appreciate specific guidance on mapping the UI selection criteria to DI API properties/methods.
Thank you for your support.
Best regards,
serena

entry.title: Joining two SAC Planning Models on common key
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I have a case that doesn't seem very sophisticated to me, but I can't really find a solution in SAC.

I have one model (PC_SALARY_GRPS), which has the Gross Salaries for every pay grade and month, where the users are also able to plan pay increases in 4 different versions. Then there is a second model (PC_DIV_POSITIONS), which has all roles that exist in a division. The role ID has the Role_Pay and the Incumbent_Pay as attributes. Those match the key of the pay grade from model PC_SALARY_GRPS.

What I basically want to achieve is joining the two models to get the gross salary to model PC_DIV_POSITIONS. I.e. if it were SQL I'd want to do something like:

SELECT p.*, s.Gross_Salary FROM PC_DIV_POSITIONS p
JOIN PC_SALARY_GRPS s ON p.[Role_ID].[Incumbent_Salary] = s.Salary_Group AND p.CALMONTH = s.CALMONTH AND p.VERSION = s.VERSION

I think I should be able to achieve this using data actions. I tried different approaches with the LINK formula, but that didn't lead anywhere. That may be because I'm an absolute beginner to data actions, though.

Do you have some advice for me?

Thanks!

entry.title: FEB_BADI & FIEB_CHANGE_BS_DATA Not getting trigered from FIORI Manage Incoming Payment File (F1680)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We have an enhancement implemented in BAdI FEB_BADI, method CHANGE_POSTING_DATA, to adjust posting logic for some bank accounts.
This enhancement has been working correctly for years when processing bank statements with FF_5 / FF.5 (SAP Gui), and it is still triggered today when we test with FF_5.

After moving to Fiori, the end users started using the app F1680 – Manage Incoming Payment Files.
We noticed that this Fiori app completely bypasses the FEB_BADI implementation, so our custom posting logic is no longer executed.

Same for FIEB_CHANGE_BS_DATA.

I am looking for the correct enhancement spot to re-implement the same logic in S/4HANA.

Many thanks in advance.

Oussama.

entry.title: PLM Tech Uncovered: SAP Integrated Product Development Update 11/2025
entry.content:
Welcome back to PLM Tech Uncovered! I’m excited to take you through the latest enhancements in SAP Integrated Product Development. There’s a lot to unpack, so let’s get started!

Requirements Management and Systems Modeling

Manage properties for a permission

You can now manage permissions at a property level within a requirement model. In the Properties panel of a requirement model, a new option Property Permissions is added to the Permissions tab. Use this option to manage access control for individual properties within a requirement model.

Manage permissions for a requirement

A new tab Permissions is added to the Properties panel displayed when you select a requirement. Through this tab, you can manage the permission levels of users and groups for a requirement within its requirement model. Previously, users can only edit permissions on the requirement models.

Authorization and permission enhancements

You can now apply selected permissions to all child requirements, throughout the entire requirement hierarchy. You can perform this action by using the Copy Permissions to All Children option. It is available in the Permissions tab in Properties panel for repositories (and its objects) and requirement models.

Specification Management 

Property data transfer between specifications 

Property data transfer saves time and improves accuracy by eliminating manual re-entry, ensuring consistency and reducing errors across related specifications. You can transfer individual properties or use property templates to update existing specifications in the Manage Specifications app.

Visualization

Execute script from Browse app

You can now run scripts for a visualization from the Browse app. You can perform this by using the Execute Script option available in the option (More) on a visualization card.

🔔  To stay informed until the next update you can: 

  • Subscribe to the What’s New Viewer on SAP Integrated Product Development Help Portal 
  • Join our LinkedIn group SAP Solutions for PLM
  • Visit us at www.sap.com/IPD  

📣  Want to give feedback on SAP Integrated Product Development?
🎥  Watch this short video to see how, then send your feedback directly from the app—we’d love to hear from you.

entry.title: Re: Security roles in select source of supply
entry.content:
Hi,

In the Source of Supply popup, the icon highlighted in the screenshot is the personalization icon, which allows end users to add or remove columns (including the Price field). This personalization capability is controlled at user level and cannot be locked or disabled in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

  • SAP’s “Adapt Filters / Adapt Columns” icon is part of standard Fiori table personalization.

  • In Public Cloud, SAP does not provide configuration options to:

    • Disable this icon,

    • Freeze the screen layout, or

    • Prevent users from re-adding a field that exists in the underlying data model.

As a result, even if you remove the Price field through UI adaptation or hide it initially, users can re-personalize the view and add it back, as long as the field is technically available.

If your security policy requires a full lock of table personalization, this would need SAP enhancement.
You can raise it via the SAP Influence Portal, as this option is not supported in current standard functionality.

  1. Get started by opening SAP Customer Influence SAP Continuous Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition
  2.  Register and accept the Terms of Use
  3.  Choose a session of your interest
  4. Create and submit your improvement request
  5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

Thank you,

Krithika

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA for Utilities 2023 Market Process Management...
entry.content:
Hi @jack_tie,

the product “Market process management for utilities for SAP S/4HANA” (MPM) will be in maintenance until 31.12.2027, as already committed in the Release Availability Document. It is an add-on to SAP S/4HANA Utilities. Maintenance of current Release SAP S/4HANA MPM UTIL 2305 is extended to 31.12.2027 to fulfill the above general maintenance commitment. 

With regards to MPM, there are no plans for a follow up Release, meaning no release of MPM will be made available on SAP S/4HANA 2025. The Application Process Engine (APE), MCM-Adaptor and all other features in technical components APE and UCOM have been moved into the S/4HANA Utilities stack with S/4HANA 2025. They are now part of S/4HANA Utilities from that release onwards and underly standard maintenance commitment for that product.

We believe, that with the move of the major MPM components into the standard SAP S/4HANA Utilities product, our customers will have certainty on maintenance planning by SAP, and have even higher confidence in introducing the process framework. With the extension of maintenance on S/4HANA MPM UTIL 2305 to end of 2027, we provide more time to transition from IDXGC to APE and upgrade to S/4HANA 2025.

Also see 1745581 - Release strategy for the ABAP Add-On IDXGC - SAP for Me and 2708496 - Release strategy and Maintenance Information for the ABAP add-ons APE and UIAPE - SAP for Me

Best regards

Sebastian Schiefer

Head of Product Management Utilities Market Communication & Distributed Energy Resources
Industry Product Engineering
SAP SE

entry.title: Becoming a Data Architect: Your First Step in the Data Architecture Learning Journey
entry.content:
In an era where data drives innovation, strategy, and transformation, Data Architecture has become the cornerstone of enterprise success. To bridge the gap between technical expertise and strategic impact, SAP Data Architecture experts and the SIX learning team have collaborated to introduce the "Becoming a Data Architecture Course (Foundational)," the first stage in the "Becoming a Data Architect" program.  
 
This course empowers aspiring architects, data professionals, data solution experts, and Data enthusiasts to master the principles, paradigms, and frameworks that define modern enterprise data architecture. 
 
Overview of the Learning 
 
The Data Architecture course is structured as a learning pyramid, designed to build expertise layer by layer — from foundational principles to strategic business impact. 
 
At its base lies Unit 1: Foundational Concepts, which anchors learners in the essential principles of modelling, metadata management, and architectural alignment. It serves as the bedrock upon which all modern data paradigms and governance strategies are built. You will understand the basic terminology and fundamentals of Data Architecture, including conceptual, logical, and physical data models, which ensure efficiency and scalability. Understand what metadata and semantic management are and how data architecture integrates with enterprise architecture frameworks such as Zachman and TOGAF. 
In the second unit (Unit 2: Modern Paradigms & Integration), we cover contemporary data architecture patterns, including Data Mesh, Data Fabric, Data Lake, and Data Lakehouse, and compare them based on different considerations. The unit also explores integration and pipeline approaches, such as ETL and ELT, and when to use each.  
In Unit 3: Governance, Security & Strategic Impact – we cover details of establishing comprehensive data governance frameworks (including stewardship and data lineage) and integrate security and privacy controls to ensure compliance with relevant regulations and secure AI/ML use cases. As data ecosystems grow, governance and security become the bedrock of trust and compliance. This unit develops your ability to design, secure, and align enterprise data strategies. 
And finally, in Unit 4, Communicating Data Value: A great architect not only designs systems, but they also inspire transformation. This final unit reinforces the communication and leadership skills necessary to effect change. We talk about how you can communicate Architectural Value: Articulate the limitations of the current data landscape ("as-is") and present a compelling, business-focused narrative for the benefits of the proposed future-state ("to-be") architecture (quality, cost, scale).  
 
Who Should Take This Course
 
This course is designed for data professionals at every stage of their career who want to evolve from technical roles into strategic architectural leadership. Ideal participants include, but are not limited to:  
  1. Data Engineers and Modellers seeking to advance into architectural roles. 
  2. Solution and Enterprise Architects aiming to strengthen their data design and governance foundations. 
  3. Business Intelligence and Analytics professionals who need to understand how architecture underpins data-driven decision-making. 
  4. IT and Transformation leaders looking to align data systems with business outcomes. 
 
Why take this course? 
Because modern organisations need architects who understand both technology and business value. By mastering foundational architecture principles, you’ll: 
  1. Improve data discoverability, quality, and governance. 
  2. Learn how to connect data architecture to enterprise goals. 
  3. Gain the credibility to influence strategic data decisions. 
  4. Prepare for the SAP Certified Data Architect* specialization that is planned for launch in 2026 
 
How to Start Your Course
You can get started today without any prerequisites via the learning.sap.com: Becoming an SAP Data Architect (Foundational)  
But this is just a starting point - Becoming a Data Architect is not just about mastering tools or technologies—it’s about developing architectural thinking. This Foundational Concepts course sets the stage for you to evolve into a strategic leader who can design, communicate, and drive data transformation in any organization.  
 
In 2026, we plan to launch the Data Architecture Advanced course and Data Architect Certification (C_BDCDA), which will provide you with a comprehensive path to becoming a skilled Data Architect.  
 
Ready to begin? 
Visit SAP Learning and enrol in the Becoming an SAP Data Architect – Foundational course today!

entry.title: Extend the Document Stroe of Analytical Cell Comments by Developer Extensibility
entry.content:
This blog explains how to extend the Document Store by developer extensibility in Embedded Steampunk of S4 Public Cloud. The following contents are covered:

  • Introduction of cell commenting feature and Document Store. 
  • Prerequisites of Document Store developer extensibility。
  • Extend Document Store by developer extensibility.

1. Introduction of cell commenting feature and Document Store 

In some Review Booklet and Multidimensional Analysis  (MDA) Apps, users might see a “comment” button in the side panel and then users can add comments on a data cell of the grid through the comments side panel. This feature is called Cell Commenting, as shown in the following figure: 

 

To enable the Cell Commenting feature the analytical cube and query must be enabled with Document Store which stores the context of the cell, including the fixed filters in the filter bar, the dynamic filters and the selected dimensions on row and column.

Document Store consists of two artifacts:

  • Document Store Table: a database table to store the cell context.
  • Document Store CDS View: a special category of CDS view which selects from the Document Store Table and has annotation @analytics.dataCategory: #DOCSTORE.

The fields in the Document Store are pure technical fields related to the dimensions of the cube. A dimension in cube can have maximum 6 related fields as following: 

Naming RuleMeaningData Type
TRA_* Transient Characteristic The same data type as the dimension 

SVA_* 

Single Character Variable 

Char(1) 

SVH_* 

Single Variable for Hierarchy 

Char(1) 

HIO_* 

Hierarchy Object 

Char(30) 

HNM_* 

Hierarchy Name 

Char(30) 

HNO_* 

Hierarchy Node Object 

Char(23) 

*: could be the same field name in cube, for example TRA_COMPANYCODE, or a number. The maximum length of the field name in the Document Store is 18, so when the length of cube field name plus the prefix(TRA_, SVA_, ...) exceeds the maximum, a number should be used instead, for example TRA_00001, TRA_00002. Just make sure the field name is unique in the table.

The enablement of Document Store for analytical cube and query include:

  • The Document Store is created for the analical cube view.
  • The analytical cube view is associated to the Document Store CDS view and the association is exposed.
  • The analytical query view contain the Document Store association exposed in cube view. 

For SAP delivered Review Booklets or Multidimensional Analysis applications, if the commenting feature is enabled the above steps have already been done. 

 

2. Prerequisites of Document Store Developer Extensibility 

When a document store enabled cube is extended with a new dimension field by developer extensibility or key user extensibility, the document store will not be extended automatically. In this situation, this new extended field cannot support Cell Commenting. It means if the new dimension is used in the report layout(added in the row or column) or the filter, an error will be raised when you try to create a comment on the cell. Nevertheless, if the new dimension is not used in the report layout or filter, the cell commenting is not impacted, and you can still add comments for the data cells. 

Please be known that if you extend the cube and query with a measure type field, extension is not needed on the Document Store. Only new added dimension fields need the extension in Document Store accordingly. 

There are some prerequisites to extend the Document Store by developer extensibility: 

  • The Document Table and Document CDS View must be C0 released for ‘Use in Cloud Development’.
  • The Document Table should have some extensibility annotations which start with ‘@AbapCatalog.enhancement’. 
  • The Document CDS View should also have the extensibility annotations which start with ‘@AbapCatalog.extensibility’. 

If the prerequisites are not met, please ask SAP to enable the C0 release. 

 

3. Extend the Document Store by Developoer Extensibility

When you have extended the cube with a dimension field, either by developer extensibility or key user extensibility, and want to extend the document store, please follow the steps below. 

3.1 Find Dimention Type

  • Open "Relation Explorer" in ABAP Developer Tool (in the cube right click and select 'Show In→ Relation Explorer) 
  • Check the details on the new-added dimension on the right side, please pay attention to the text in the “[ ]”, it means which kind of dimension it is.  

Ralation Explorer

[Hier] means the dimension has a foreign key association and the association target has hierarchy assocation.

For every new extended dimension field, two types of fields need to be added in the Document CDS View. They are denoted by: 

                  @analytics.document.type: #TRA  

                  @analytics.document.type: #SVA

If the extended dimension has [Hier], four additional fields need to be added in the Document Store CDS View. They are denoted by:

                  @analytics.document.type: #SVH 

                  @analytics.document.type: #HIO  

                  @analytics.document.type: #HNM 

                  @analytics.document.type: #HNO  

As said above, the TRA field should have the same data type as the field in the cube. For key user extensibility case, you can find the data type of new extended dimension in the following way: open the cube view in ADT, and put the cursor on the name of the cube, then press F2 you will see the information of the cube, as the following figure shows:

3.2 Extend the Document Store Table

 Assume a new dimension field PostingLevel_2 has been extended in the cube view. It has a foreign key association I_CnsldtnPostingLevel which has a hierarchy association _PostgLevelHierNode, then 6 fields need to be extended in the document store table and document store CDS view respectively. 

To extend the Document Table, in the ADT of your Embedded Steampunk development system, right click the package, select New -> Other ABAP Repository Object->Structure. Give the name and description, then you can create the structure (which is actually a structure extension). Assume the Document Store table name is ‘test_doc_store_tab’, then a new structure extension would be created with the name  ‘test_doc_store_ext” as the following code: 

extend type test_doc_store_tab with test_doc_store_ext { 
  tra_00062_dcu        : fc_plevl; 
  sva_00062_dcu        : abap.char(1); 
  svh_00062_dcu        : abap.char(1); 
  hnm_00062_dcu        : abap.char(30); 
  hno_00062_dcu        : abap.char(32); 
  hio_00062_dcu        : abap.char(30); 
}

You can also use template ‘appendStructure’ to create the skeleton of the code. 

A correct suffix should be added for the fields according to the definition of annotation @AbapCatalog.enhancement.fieldSuffix  in the Document Store Table. Here ‘dcu’ is used as an example. You should also add prefix before the name for customer development as normal. 

As the length of field name “PostingLevel_2” is more than 13, a unique number should be used instead, normally we are using the existing max number plus 1 to get the number. If the field name is short than 13, please use the field name directly, for example sva_glaccount. 

For field TRA_* the data type should be the same as the field in the cube, so here TRA_00062 uses fc_plevl. 

3.3 Extend the Document Store CDS View

Similarly, 6 fields should be added in the Document CDS View. In ADT, right click the package, select New-> Other ABAP Repository Object ->Data Definition. Write the code as following: 

extend view entity I_CDS_TST_SO_HEADER_CUBEDST with { 
  @analytics.document:{ type: #TRA , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.tra_0062_dcu as tra_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #SVA , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.sva_0062_dcu as sva_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #SVH , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.svh_0062_dcu as svh_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HNM , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.hnm_0062_dcu as hnm_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HNO , reference: 'PostingLevel_2' } 
  Persistence.hno_0062_dcu as hno_0062_dcu, 

  @analytics.document:{ type: #HIO , reference: 'PostingLevel_2 ' } 
  Persistence.hio_0062_dcu as hio_0062_dcu, 
}

You can also use the template ‘extendViewEntity’ to create the skeleton of the code.  

A correct suffix should be added for the fields according to the definition of annotation @ @AbapCatalog.extensibility.elementSuffix  in the Document Store CDS View. Here ‘dcu’ is used as an example. You should also add prefix before the name for customer development as normal. 

Here ‘Persistence’ is the data source of the Document Store CDS View, that is the Document Store Table. Refer to the following example of a Document Store CDS View: 

                       

In the above example, 6 fields are added. For the simple case without hierarchy association, only two fields(TRA_* and SVA_*) are needed.

After the above stpes you will finish the developer extension of Document Store. You can verify the extesion by checking the information of the Document CDS View (press F2 on the view name). Now the users are able to add comments for the new extended dimension.

 

Further Links and Resources

 SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionSAP S/4HANA/SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
Review Bookletslink to help.sap.comlink to help.sap.com
Multidimensional Analysislink to help.sap.comlink to help.sap.com
Cell Commentinglink to help.sap.comlink to help.sap.com

entry.title: Understanding how to set up E-Verify in SuccessFactors in Onboarding
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss how E-Verify works with SuccessFactors onboarding and some of the common questions raised by customers and consultants.  We will discuss three main scenarios.  This article is aimed at non USA consultants who may not be familiar with the I9 and compliance process.  We will cover two main processes

  • Customer wanting to set up E-Verify for the first time with SuccessFactors Onboarding
  • Customer migrating from Onboarding 1.0 to 2.0

 

Background

E-Verify is a free, web-based system that allows employers to confirm the employment eligibility of their new hires in the United States. It compares information from the employee's I-9 to records from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Social Security Administration (SSA) to verify the employee is authorized to work. While it's voluntary for most employers, some are required to use it by state law or federal contracts.

During the hiring process a candidate completes ‘Section 1’ of the I9 during the onboarding process.  This is then validated by the ‘company representative’ they are being employed by, this is known as ‘completing section 2’.  Once this is completed the standard integration from SuccessFactors onboarding creates an E-Verify case and checks the data.  Depending on the data, it may be automatically approved/closed or further action may by the company representative.

You can set up I9s without E-Verify as they require two separate configurations

You can set up a test E-Verify account in SuccessFactors onboarding to see how the end to end process works.

Customer who are moving to SuccessFactors onboarding may already have an E-Verify account so we will look at how they might be impacted.

Customer wanting to set up E-Verify for the first time with SuccessFactors Onboarding

If the customer has not used Onboarding 1.0 or the have their own E-Verify account they will need to request a new MOU from the SAP E-Verify team.   This is detailed in this KBA

2421435 - How to create an Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) for E-Verify [Compliance] - Onboarding module - SAP for Me

They can’t use the old MOU in SuccessFactors onboarding as this MOU is set up with a different Employing Agent.  SAP are they Designated Agent for our customers.  It is important that when you request the new MOU organization don’t close down the old MOU until they are happy that everyone has been processed as once an MOU has been closed it can’t re-opened easily.

Finally, customers need to email the SAP E-Verify team to request an MOU and you  can’t do this via webservices.  Once an MOU has been provided this will need to be added to the compliance centre as shown below.

You will still need to define the account type.

Two rules need to be configured.

The ‘E-Verify enablement rule’ needs to be created.  This rule controls who needs to complete E-Verify, this can be done for all hires in USA, or you can trigger E-Verify for certain legal entities.

Finally, the rule for ‘Corporate representative’ will control who will need to complete any E-Verify actions generated.  It can be the same groups as section 2 or different groups.  Either way you will need to ensure the people have the correct E-Verify permission in RBP.

 

 

Customer migrating from Onboarding 1.0 to 2.0

If you are already using E-Verify in 1.0 then you can use the same MOU.  If you are not using E-Verify in 1.0 but would like to do so then you would need to request an MOU as described above.

When you use E-Verify with SuccessFactors onboarding whether 1.0 or 2.0 you do not get a username/password to log into E-Verify directly.  All interactions with E-Verify are done via SuccessFactors, including manually creating an E-Verify case.

Hopefully this article will answer some of the questions around setting up E-Verify in SuccessFactors,

entry.title: KSeF 2.0 Test Environment: Automate the Retrieval of Electronic Documents with the Cloud Edition
entry.content:
You are setting up your system for the new invoice format required for KSeF 2.0 and want to understand how to test automated retrieval of invoices from the tax authority portal to achieve end-to-end processing of electronic documents.

With the Schedule Jobs app in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition, you can create one job that automates the retrieval of supplier or self-billing invoices from the tax authority portal to your business system (for example, SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP) . This makes the following activities in your business system obsolete:

  • Processing eDocument Inbound Messages
  • Processing Incoming Messages with Additional Filters
  • Processing eDocument Status Message
  • Processing Status Messages for Multiple eDocuments

Meaning, you no longer use the eDocument Inbound Message Handler for these activities. Instead, you use Schedule Jobs app.

How it works?

  1. You schedule a job in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition. The system automatically creates a request based on the job configuration.
  2. The cloud edition takes invoice data from Krajowy System e-Faktur (KSeF), a platform from the Polish tax authority used to exchange electronic invoices.
  3. The cloud edition decrypts retrieved invoices, creates visualization as PDF files and pushes to the destination business system selected for the job.
  4. The business system creates the electronic document and updates its status. The XML (FA(3)) and PDF files are available in the history of the electronic document. Here you can also check if any duplicate documents were retrieved.
    Note: To see the attached XML (FA(3)) and PDF files, select the electronic document and open Attachments in the Manage Electronic Documents app, or History in the eDocument Cockpit transaction.

Test Use Cases

In this blog, I share details on two key scenarios for downloading invoices that you might want to apply with the Schedule Jobs app:

  • Downloading purchase invoices
  • Downloading sales invoices for self-billing

Prerequisites

You have already performed the general integration settings for test environment as described in this blog: KSeF 2.0 Test Environment: Setup and Integrate Your System with the Cloud Edition.

Now, you can test configuring automated jobs for retrieving your invoices from tax authority portal using the Schedule Jobs app.  To access the app, go to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition launchpad in your associated SAP BTP subaccount. See Scheduling Jobs.

Configuration is guided through a step-by-step wizard:

  1. Define the general settings for the job, by selecting:
    • Process Flow:  Retrieving Documents for E-Invoices Through KseF (PL)
    • Identification Number: Select the NIP number you have set for communication type E-Invoices Through KSeF 2.0 (PL). See Managing Communication Settings.

  2. Configure additional properties required by KSeF 2.0 to provide the data to the cloud edition. This is where you pay attention to achieve the scenarios.

    Scenario 1: You want to schedule job to retrieve invoices where your company is the buyer.

    • subjectType: Subject2 (Buyer)
    • dateType: Issue (Use for KSeF 2.0 test environment).
      Note: Later, for production, it’s recommended to use PermanentStorage (based on archival date) to avoid missing invoices.
    • Buyer Identifier Type: Select Nip or VatUe. 
    • Buyer Identifier Value: Enter the identification number of your company according to the type you selected.

    Scenario 2: You want to schedule a job to retrieve invoices issued under self-invoicing mode where your company acts as the seller.

    • subjectType: Subject1 (Seller)
    • dateType: Issue (Use for KSeF 2.0 test environment).
      Note: Later, for production, it’s recommended to use PermanentStorage (based on archival date) to avoid missing invoices.
    • sellerNIP: Your company NIP number
    • isSelfInvoicing: Select the checkbox

  3. Define the frequency of your job. Example configuration can be:
    • Every 2 hours – the cloud edition will send a request for retrieving the invoices every 2 hours and will get the invoices created in between.
    • One-Time – you can use this to get the invoices for a certain period in the past, for example, the period before the first run of your recurring job.

  4. Select the destination you created for the business system in which you want to receive the documents. See Setting Up Connectivity.

Once you save your configuration, you can monitor the results of your job runs – time details, status, results, troubleshooting steps. See Viewing Results of a Job Run.

For more information on KSeF 2.0 related features covered by SAP, you can access the Regulatory Change Manager for Mandatory e-Invoicing through KSeF in Poland.

entry.title: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Charan Ravikumar and Maria Kondratyeva

 

Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and Joule agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency. 

However, we recognize that the partner landscape, with its mix of TDD, PAYG, and subscription accounts, introduces unique complexities. Many of you have asked the essential question: "How do we, as partners, get Joule Studio set up correctly in our environments?"

This guide is built specifically for you. It synthesizes insights from our support channels and direct partner feedback to address your most common challenges, such as multi-global account integrations and navigating the new SAP Build licensing in TDD environments. Whether you're starting fresh or integrating existing services, this post outlines everything you need to know to get started efficiently and cost-effectively.

Let's get started!

Critical Prerequisites: Licensing & Plans

Before diving into the setup flows, let's clarify three critical concepts that are often sources of confusion for partners. Getting these right from the start will save you significant time and effort.

The "New" SAP Build Plan (build-default)

Many partners have existing SAP Build entitlements on a legacy "standard" plan. To use Joule Studio, you must use the build-default plan, specifically for SAP Build Process Automation.

  • Critical Action: Do NOT order a new, separate SAP Build subscription! In your existing Partner TDD Global Account (under a PAYG model), the entitlement for the new plan is already available.
    • You simply need to navigate to the Service Marketplace in your BTP cockpit and activate the SAP Build Process Automation service, ensuring you select the build-default plan during setup.
  • Note: Ordering a new subscription instead of activating the existing entitlement often leads to selecting the wrong plan and creates unnecessary account complexity.
  • TDD Licensing Options:
    • License the Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP for cloud test, demo, and development (SKU 8009282). This grants you access to free "Fair Use Limits" for SAP Build (Recommended)
    • Alternative (Subscription): A subscription-based SAP Build TDD developer license (SKU 8019951) is also available, but it does not include the Fair Use Limits.
  • What is Fair Use Limits (FUL): The Fair Use Limit where the partner is provided an entitled specified threshold amount of TDD services free of charge per billing cycle. It’s designed to support development without unexpected costs.
    • Please refer to this link for more details on FUL - https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/assets/products/tech_plat/dgl/30/23/SAP1223023.html

  Joule Entitlement

    • Joule for Consultant and Joule for Developers are different licenses and not connected with Joule Studio license and its activation.
  • Cost for Custom Skills: There is no additional cost or AI Unit consumption for the orchestration and invocation of custom Joule skills built with Joule Studio's current features.
    • However, the underlying services your skill uses (e.g., SAP Build Process Automation) will still follow their standard commercial models (e.g., consumption against your Fair Use Limits).

The Multi-Global Account Scenario

It is very common for partners to have their Joule entitlement in a TDD subscription based global account and their SAP Build entitlement in a separate TDD PAYG global account. This is a supported scenario.

  • The Golden Thread: The key to making this work is to ensure that both global accounts are federated under the same SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS). This single identity provider is what allows the two systems to trust each other and integrate seamlessly.
  • To run Joule Booster or Joule Formation (see table below), select the 2 global accounts you have.

Understanding Your Integration Flow: Starting Points and Required Steps

This table outlines the five primary scenarios for integrating SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA in the future text) capabilities into the Joule Studio environment.  Identify which flow best matches your current setup, whether you’re starting fresh or have existing SBPA or Joule subscriptions. This will immediately provide you with the exact action steps and critical notes required for a successful connection.

 

Starting Point

Key Action Steps

The partner is setting up both Joule and SBPA from scratch. 

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect Joule and SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The partner already has Joule (Booster provisioned) and now links the existing SBPA (it must be a build-default plan) for Joule Studio.

  1. Verify SBPA Prerequisites: Ensure SBPA entitlement is on the build-default plan (standard plan is not compatible).
  2. Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  3. Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  4. Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    1. Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    2. Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    3. Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    4. Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  5. Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  6. Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  7. Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    1. joule_extensibility
    2. end_user 

The partner has an existing SBPA (on the correct build-default plan) and now wants to add Joule.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above for Joule. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect the new Joule to the existing SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The partner already has both services (on the correct plan); they just need to be linked for Joule Studio.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The partner has both, but SBPA is on the standard plan (requires an upgrade).

  • Upgrade SBPA to the correct plan (build-default).
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

FAQ & Common Pitfalls for Partners

Q1: I don't see the build-default plan for SAP Build in my TDD account. How do I get it?   Do not order a new paid subscription. Ensure you have the correct TDD account with BTP PAYG license. Then, go to your BTP Cockpit -> Service Marketplace. Find "SAP Build Process Automation" and create a new instance/subscription, making sure to select the build-default plan.

Q2: My Joule and SAP Build are in different Global Accounts. Is that a problem?  No, this is a common and supported partner scenario. The absolute requirement is that both global accounts' subaccounts use the same Cloud Identity Service (IAS) tenant for authentication.

Q3: I ran the booster, but Joule Studio doesn't appear, or I get an error when deploying. What's wrong? This is almost always one of three issues:

  1. Mismatched Identity Services: Your Joule and SBPA subaccounts are pointing to different IAS tenants.
  2. Incorrect SBPA Plan: You are still on the "standard" plan instead of "build-default".
  3. Incorrect Joule SKU: Make sure you have a correct Joule license under Joule service TDD SKU (8018168) at no cost. To be on the safe side, please contact with your account manager, making sure you have right SKU enabled.
  4. Missing Role Collections: Your user is missing the joule_extensibility and end_user roles in the Joule subaccount, or the necessary developer roles in the SBPA subaccount.

Q4: I followed the steps, but deployment still fails with an IdP error: This points to a deeper trust configuration issue. Verify the trust settings between your BTP subaccounts and the IAS tenant. Ensure the Integration with Joule Formation status is Ready. If the issue persists, we recommend logging a free Technical Advisory request via the SAP BTP Technical Advisory service for expert assistance.

Q5: I am experiencing an ongoing issue and require further assistance. How may I contact you? Please submit a free Technical Advisory request via the SAP BTP Technical Advisory service for expert assistance.

Helpful Resources for Setup and Activation 

  • How to get started with Joule Studio
  • Provisioning Joule Studio 
  • Enabling Joule Studio for existing customers 
  • Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Reference Architecture for Joule Studio 
  • Activate Joule Studio in 5 Simple Steps

entry.title: Re: Delete FD32 Customer Credit limits
entry.content:
When you delete limits in FD32, you are working with the old credit management tables (KNKK). In S/4HANA, Sales orders no longer check KNKK. They use the new credit management engine (FSCM Credit Management) which is integrated with the Business Partner (BP) master data and Credit Control Areas. That is why in FI (FB70), no warning appears, because FI still looks at KNKK (classic). In SD (Sales Order), warnings appear, because SD checks FSCM credit exposure, not KNKK. So even though you deleted the limits in FD32, the FSCM credit master data (BP → Credit Segment) still exists and is being evaluated.

If you don’t want credit checks for COD customers, you have a few options:

Go to BP transaction → Role: UKM000 – Credit Management. In the Credit Segment Data, either remove the credit limit, and set the Check Rule or Risk Category so that no credit check is performed. Alternatively, assign a special Risk Category (e.g., “COD”) that is excluded from credit checks in customizing.

In OVA8, you can configure that for certain combinations (e.g., Sales Area + Risk Category + Credit Control Area), no credit check is triggered. Assign COD customers to this special category.

For COD customers, assign payment terms that are excluded from credit checks. In customizing, you can set rules so that orders with COD terms bypass credit management.

entry.title: Re: Delivery Note/Package Query
entry.content:
Hello,

Here is the correct query:

SELECT T0."DocNum", T1."ItemCode", SUM(T1."Quantity") AS "DelQty", A1."Quantity" AS "PackQty"
FROM ODLN T0
INNER JOIN DLN1 T1 ON T0."DocEntry" = T1."DocEntry"
LEFT JOIN
(SELECT T2."DocEntry", T2."ItemCode", SUM(T2."Quantity") AS "Quantity" FROM DLN8 T2 GROUP BY T2."DocEntry", T2."Itemcode") AS A1 ON T1."DocEntry" = A1."DocEntry" AND T1."ItemCode" = A1."ItemCode"
WHERE T0."DocNum" = '15079'
GROUP BY T0."DocNum", T1."ItemCode", A1."Quantity"
HAVING SUM(T1."Quantity") <> ISNULL(A1."Quantity",0)

entry.title: Comment SAP MM peut transformer le processus d’achats dans une entreprise
entry.content:
Le module SAP MM (Materials Management) est l’un des piliers des systèmes SAP pour la gestion des achats et des stocks. Une bonne utilisation de SAP MM peut révolutionner le processus d’approvisionnement, en le rendant plus rapide, plus précis et plus efficace.

 Automatisation des achats SAP MM permet de générer automatiquement les demandes d’achat, les commandes

fournisseurs et les bons de réception, en réduisant les erreurs humaines et en accélérant le cycle P2P (Procure-to-Pay).

Meilleure gestion des fournisseurs

Le module centralise toutes les informations sur les fournisseurs : données de contact, conditions d’achat, historique de commandes, performances, etc. Cela facilite la sélection des meilleurs fournisseurs et le suivi des KPI.

Optimisation des stocks

SAP MM permet de suivre en temps réel les stocks disponibles, les mouvements de matériel, et les niveaux de réapprovisionnement. Cela réduit les ruptures de stock et les surstocks, améliorant la gestion du capital.

 Intégration avec les autres modules SAP

Grâce à l’intégration avec SAP FI (finance) et SAP SD (ventes), SAP MM garantit que toutes les transactions d’achats ont un impact direct sur la comptabilité et la chaîne logistique. Cela offre une visibilité complète et un contrôle précis des coûts.

Analyses et reporting avancés

SAP MM fournit des rapports détaillés et des tableaux de bord pour suivre les performances des achats, analyser les écarts de prix et anticiper les besoins futurs. Les décisions deviennent plus rapides et basées sur des données fiables.

En adoptant SAP MM, une entreprise peut transformer son processus d’approvisionnement :plus de rapidité et d’efficacité,

  • moins d’erreurs,

  • meilleure visibilité sur les stocks et les fournisseurs,

  • décisions basées sur des données précises.

SAP MM n’est pas seulement un outil informatique, c’est un véritable levier stratégique pour la performance des achats.

SAP ERP Cloud SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement

entry.title: Re: The post date of Returns Delivery can't be decided
entry.content:
The posting date of the journal entry is not taken directly from the Actual Goods Movement Date you enter in the returns delivery. Instead, the system uses the Release Date of the inspection document (the day you actually complete and release the inspection) as the posting date. That is why

  • You entered goods movement date = 2025‑11‑20.
  • You entered inspection date = 2025‑11‑20.
  • But the inspection was only released on 2025‑12‑04.
  • The system posts the accounting document with posting date = 2025‑12‑04.

This is by design in Public Cloud. The financial posting is tied to the release of the inspection lot, not the physical goods movement date you type in.

entry.title: The Power of UI Flexibility in SAP Project and Resource Management
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s fast-moving projects, waiting for a development cycle to adjust a field, add a custom section, or visualize data from another system can slow down productivity.
That’s where UI Flexibility in SPRM Project Management comes in.

UI Flexibility allows key users — not just developers — to adapt and extend their applications without changing the source code. With just a few clicks, you can:

  • Add or reorder sections.
  • Embed external web pages or dashboards.
  • Forward live data from SPRM Project Management into external tools.

Its flexibility designed for business agility.

 

What UI Flexibility Enables

With UI Flexibility, key users can:

  • Create custom sections in the existing application layout.
  • Embed external content, such as web pages, apps, or analytics dashboards.
  • Propagate data from SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT to embedded content via URL parameters.
  • Leverage Public APIs to exchange information between the host app and embedded systems.

[Screenshot – Example of a custom embedded section with an planning calendar]

You can extend your SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT workspace to include the tools and data you use daily.

 

Architecture Overview

UI Flexibility is built on top of the UFlex service and integrates directly with the SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT application framework.
It ensures all extensions stay secure, modular, and maintainable.

Architecture Layers

Layer

Description

SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT Application

Provides the core logic and standard UI containers.

UI Flexibility Layer

Allows runtime configuration of new sections and embedded content.

Embedded Content Layer

Hosts external pages or applications within secure iframes.

Public API Layer

Enables controlled, secure data exchange between SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT and custom apps.

 

[Diagram – UI Flexibility and Embedded Content Architecture]

 

Embedding External Content

UI Flexibility supports embedding external web pages or applications directly within SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT screens.
Below there are examples for possible implementations:

  • Project dashboards
  • Reporting apps
  • Custom micro-frontends
  • Process documentation or help content

Each embedded component runs independently. This ensures that even if one service experiences issues, the rest of your application remains stable.

[Screenshot – Embedded external team calendar example]

Important Note: The embedded app is isolated from SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT. Any data exchange should occur through defined URL parameters or Public APIs only.

 

Data Propagation and Public API Access

How it Works

When configuring an embedded section, you can select which SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT data should be forwarded to the embedded content via the URL i.e. test.com/Projects/{Uuid}/{CollaborationOwner}
This enables the external page to operate in context — for example, knowing which project or object the user is viewing.

Example Uses:

  • Display custom KPIs using project data.
  • Trigger external workflows when a user opens a section.
  • Write back updates to analytics tools using the Public API.

Tip: Combine URL-based data propagation with Public API calls for dynamic, two-way integrations.

 

Technical Insight: Interaction Model

Although UI Flexibility gives freedom to embed and integrate, it respects browser and framework boundaries.

Key facts:

  • Embedded apps are rendered in iframes.
  • Browsers restrict direct event sharing between the host and iframe. This is done via the sandbox flags which can also be removed, but this is not recommended.
  • Edit or Save events in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT are not automatically communicated to the embedded app.
  • Each embedded component should manage its own logic and data lifecycle.

Hint: Design embedded apps as standalone micro-applications that can run independently, even outside the host context.

 

 Example Setup: Creating an Embedded Section


Here’s how to configure your first embedded section using UI Flexibility.

  1. Go to UI Flexibility Settings in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT.
  2. Select “Add New Section”.
  3. Choose Embedded Content as the section type.
  4. Enter the URL of your external web page or app.
  5. (Optional) Select which SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT fields to pass as URL parameters.
  6. Save and refresh — your new embedded section appears instantly.

[Screenshot – UI Flexibility setup]

Result: The embedded content behaves as a seamless part of your interface, while staying fully isolated and easy to maintain.

 

What You Can Achieve

Here’s what teams across projects are already doing with UI Flexibility:

  • Embedding live dashboards that update in real time.
  • Integrating specialized reporting tools.
  • Launching external workflow systems from within SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT.
  • Displaying custom KPIs per project, using propagated data.

 

Visual Demo Plan

For upcoming internal showcases, we’ll include the following visuals:

  1. UI Flexibility – Creating an Embedded Section

     


     

  2. Rearrange sections with UI Flexibility (drag and drop)

     

 

Conclusion

UI Flexibility in SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT bridges the gap between business agility and technical governance.
It empowers key users to personalize their workspace, bring in the data and tools they need, and keep pace with changing business processes — all while IT retains control of the underlying architecture.

In short:

You don’t need to be a developer to make SPRM PROJECT MANAGEMENT work smarter — just flexible.

entry.content:

  1. Is the statement correct? 
  2. And if so, what data is transferred?
  3. In which cases is data transmitted to LinkedIn?
  4. Is there technical documentation for the integration, and I don't mean instructions on how to set up the interface. We would like to have documentation that shows the data fields and also the direction in which data is sent/retrieved?
  5. Are there already European companies that are using this integration (yes/no is enough for me here)? 

Thank you in advance for answering the questions.

Bernhard

entry.title: Re: Delete FD32 Customer Credit limits
entry.content:
Delete is only possible if no open items exist for that customer in that credit control area. Alternatively, to remove the entry:

  • Set the credit limit to 0.
  • Remove the risk category (blank it out).
  • Remove the credit representative group (blank it out).
  • Save.

entry.title: Re: Introducing Application Vulnerability Report for Cloudfoundry Applications – Try It Now!
entry.content:
Hi @MatthiasL,

Thank you for your feedback! As for your questions, please find the answers below:

1) When you go to the main help page and click What's New you get no results. However going there via other link (via) does yield results

The "Whats New" section in our product documentation contains changes to the product itself, the other "Whats New" section is part of the overall BTP documentation which also mentions new services / products. We will definitely use that section when we add new features to the product itself.

2) Since it's in beta, you need to enable the beta feature for said subaccount. I feel like this should be clarified more, both from a perspective of how to activate it - but also because I get a warning when turning it on to not use it in production and that I can't disable it. So not sure if I should turn it on, even for our R&D subaccount.

We understand that concern. If you want to separate beta applications from your main R&D subaccount, you can also create a dedicated subaccount with access to beta features. By adding our technical user to other spaces, you can still scan them even if the service is subscribed in a different subaccount, as long as the subaccount which should be scanned is in one of the following data centers: cf-eu10 (including extension landscapes), cf-22 and cf-eu30. For security and compliance reasons, we can only scan in the same region the scanner resides in.

3) Still can't find it in the Discovery pages, while it is mentioned that it should be. Also, another dead link under "See Always Free Tag"

We are actively working on that.

4) It could be a bit more specific about what kind of 0 days and BTP specific things it detects (from)

During the beta, the scanner will only scan using the osv-scanner, when we add additional scanners we will explicitly state information about them in our documentation.

5) When clicking the Info button from BTP to the product, it brings you to another dead URL

Thank you for noticing, we are working on fixing that!

6) When searching for Vulnerability in help.sap you don't find anything, when searching for application vulnerability you sort of find it - but neither of them are listed as products (perhaps because it's in beta?)

We will have a look, it might take some time for help.sap.com to index new resources.

Best Regards,
Henry
